research.title: Tokensight | Brevis coChain: AVS Cryptoeconomic Risk Analysis

elements.comment: "Pure Wallet" is an EigenLayer AVS business model (the most secure one for newborn protocols) where no native AVS token is involved, and user fees are paid in a purely neutral denomination (like ETH). Currently, it appears that Pure Wallet is the model adopted by Brevis, though further details are lacking.
One code audit has been performed. GitHub code coverage percentage has not been publicly disclosed.

Since we are at the very early stages of EigenLayer, operators' reputation was classified as unknown, given the lack of a track record. Operator's entrenchment level indicates how entrenched Brevis ZK Coprocessor's operators are on other AVSs â€” the small number of AVSs currently live helps exacerbate this risk, in a pooled security context.

All AVSs are assigned a high operator profile risk at this early stage.

Brevis coChain enables smart contracts to trustlessly access full historical on-chain data from different chains. dApp developers can build and deploy customized queries using Brevis's SDK, which runs computations and generates off-chain ZK proofs. The query results, along with the ZK proofs, are submitted back on-chain for dApps' smart contracts to verify and consume.

Aided by restaked pooled security, advanced ZK cryptographic algorithms, and large-scale parallelization, Brevis is able to process trustless queries securely and at high throughput.

Brevis' Prover Network ensures the generation of ZK Consensus Proofs trustlessly and in-house, eliminating the need for validation from a third-party. Its security and consensus are fully and solely derived from the underlying blockchains and, subsequently, the cryptographically-sound proofs outputted by the network.

Even in the case of a 2/3 stake attack toward the Prover network, ZK-proof generation is not affected; only slight liveness issues may occur.

In a pure zero-knowledge system like Brevis, consensus is achieved internally through the generation of the ZK Consensus Proofs, making it an extremely airtight system against potential safety faults.

Degree of decentralization of the Prover network is unknown.
